												Let me preface this by saying I'm not an absolute hardcore sim-racer - I don't have a wheel or a racing rig, I just play driving games using an XBOX One controller. PCARS, DiRT Rally, Race 07, etc, etc - I own and play them all. WRC 5 is rough around the edges, but with some TLC I think the game could go from good to great. It's not DiRT Rally, but it's also not awful. It's not another Milestone travesty, so we don't have to worry about garbage like the sound dropping out after two stages.I'll start with the bad:- Robotic co-driver: You do get the option of a woman co-driver, but both male and female options are spliced from sound clips rather than smooth pace notes like DiRT Rally or Dirt 2 / 3. It's not bad (and the pace notes are effective), but it's something to note.- Poor engine sounds: The cars sound like toys.- No actual routes: The courses are approximations of the real locations. It's close, but it's not the actual course.- Wheel support: There's a limited set of supported wheels.And now for the pros:+ Classes: Junior WRC, WRC 2 and WRC. You get a good selection of classes and cars, plus all the licensed drivers and gear.+ Career mode: The team stats are slightly randomized so you get a good selection of goals to choose from. + Stages: 5 unique stages and a repeat per rally, usually in a 2-2-2 format. The stages aren't terribly long, but they are fun to drive. Finland's scary at night.+ Challenge mode: The MP challenge mode is pretty fun. Time trials on a specific stage using a specific team.Reasonably, hard-core sim racers aren't going to like this. It's a balance of arcade racing and sim racing, using a real-world license. If you want a nice introduction to rally racing, this is a good place to start. It's better than WRC 4 (which isn't saying much, admittedly, but it's a marked improvement and is a decent little racing game).7/10 - needs some work, but is playable and fun.EDIT 2015-10-14: Patch 1.03 helped with the variable framerate and set DX11 as the primary launch mode, rather than DX9. I adjusted the cons to remove the framerate issues and upped my score to 7/10. The game still needs work, but it's not bad.

												First of all, if you are looking for a rally sim, this game is not for you. I really wonder why Kylotonn Racing Games says that this game is a simulator, because it's not. Not even close, to be honest. And it's not a bad thing. Not for me, at least. Of course that it's a very negative aspect of the game, given the fact that the fans were waiting for an officially-licensed WRC simulator for ages. Unfortunately, they will need to wait a bit more. Even if it's not realistic, playing it is quite enjoyable: it makes you feel like a professional rally driver, nailing all the corners and flying through the straights. It's one of the most rewarding feelings while playing a rally game, of course. And you do not even need to practice a lot to be able to reach that level of "skill", which makes it suitable for rally lovers without too much spare time. And, even if pretty easy, nailing the stages is rewarding. Just like it would be at a simulator, but effortlessly. "Why are all the reviews negative, then?". That's something worth questioning. And it's clearly noticeable after 30 minutes into it: it's a massive step back from WRC 4, graphically, content-wise and physically. And it wasn't even a great rally game back in the days, because Milestone (old developer) wasn't able to leave the comfort zone and make something different. From WRC "1" (2010) to WRC 4 (2013), nothing changed at all, with a few exceptions (career mode was slightly improved after WRC 3, bringing classic cars and new categories). Anyway, small changes end up equalling to nothing. Mostly when pretty much everything looks the same. This is exactly why Kylotonn ended up holding the license, with a simple mission: develop the best WRC game ever made. I don't even need to mention that they failed miserably.WRC 5 is not bad. It's far away from it. The negative results are simply the reflex of disappointing the WRC fans. They were expecting a simulator, with great graphics, close to real-life stages, realistic engine sounds, convincing physics and top-notch content overall. What they got, though, was "more of the same": the only thing that they could consider as new were the updated cars, drivers and stages. Everything else, from gameplay to career mode, was the same. Nothing innovative, nothing exceptional. Just the usual. How could they expect their fans to react nicely?The cars are considerably beautiful (given the limitations), and so are the stages. It's really fun to drive fast through every country, nailing every single piece of it and feeling like the ultimate king of WRC. It's more than fun, honestly. It's amazing. That's where WRC 5 shines. The career mode is great, extremely immersive and rewarding but kinda empty at the same time. Maybe because it's exactly like every single career mode that the franchise had before. Innovations could and would be great. Why not to make something different like character customization, press conferences, etc...? Is it that hard to do? I don't think so. Kylotonn had to dig deeper and bring something jaw-dropping, but they decided to not take any risks and brought something that the players were used to. It's an arrow in the knee, considering that career mode is usually what most of the players are looking for (and multiplayer, of course).If you are a huge fan of the onboard cam, this game is going to disappoint you a little bit. It felt just like being shot from behind when I took the Lancer Evolution X to a ride through Mexico and noticed something quite unusual about the interior: believe it or not, it was the Impreza's. Yes, a Mitsubishi with a Subaru interior. This evidences how much research were done in order to bring the best WRC experience that you could ever ask for.There are lots of positive aspects, though. The cars have different liveries for each and every rally, with the respective logo (ADAC, RACC, Neste Oil Finland, etc). It's a small detail that makes a lot of difference. DiRT Rally, on the other hand, has the same sticker for each and every stage. Would be even better if it was actually an innovation, but the old Milestone titles had it as well. Same for the custom name on the window (which is incredibly immersive and extremely cool, and I am glad that Kylotonn "copied" this). Two little details that end up counting a lot.Regarding wheel support, this game is a joke. The actual list of supported wheels has less than 7 different models if I am not wrong. It's unacceptable for a 2015 game, and the devs promised a fix one year ago. Nothing yet. Continuous support is really important if you actually want your game to be popular and loved by the players.If you are just a casual looking for fun, dust and high speeds, this game is definitely worth a try. Do not pay full-price for it, though. Kylotonn is asking way too much for what the game actually offers. Wait for a sale and then buy it, download it and play it. If you are a rally lover like me, you are going to enjoy this game a lot (as long as you do not expect it to be a simulator, and also ignore the negative aspects).

												I really wish they didn't advertise the game as a simulator, because it definitely is not. What it is, however, is a casual game meant for rally and WRC fans. If you're looking for realism, you won't find it here. The tracks are mostly fictional and the car physics are simcade level at best. The visuals are serviceable but dated and are reminiscent of racing games on last gen consoles. The performance could be better, but the game should run fine on a modern low end system with some tinkering in the graphics options. With VSync off, I average around 70 fps on max settings with an r7 370 at 900p (45 fps at 1080p). Turning the shadows down a notch yielded a 10-15 fps boost.There is plenty of content to play through in the solo campaign. You start out as a junior and have to work your way up every season to become a champion.  The rally school is a really nice addition for people who aren't familiar with rally techniques. There are random leaderboard challenges that appear from time to time that serve as a bit of side content. If you just want to drive and not worry about the career, there is a quick stage mode that has every track and car unlocked. Overall, I would say the single player portion is very plain. You don't really need to do anything but drive. The car repairs, car setup, and team management have mostly been automated. While there are plenty of tracks, they are an example of quantity over quality. Most are short (<5 minutes) and have rather bland environments. Also, don't get this for multiplayer unless you have friends to play it with since it's mostly dead.tl;drIf you just want to sit back with a controller (or whatever your preference) and have some casual rallying fun, then you should get this on a sale.

The description of this game describes it as "THE racing simulation standard". Well, if that is the case, I'm not so sure how someone came to that opinion. Here is what I PERSONALLY like and don't like. Pros - WRC Licensing. I love seeing the pros and their cars. Though, I'm not certain the sound effects are spot on. Also, It would be great if there was a better viewpoint inside the car. Cons - Nothing online worked for me. I'd get errors connecting to the server. Another mode told me there were over 100 days till I could play it online. Well, alright, fair enough. I guess you need a following to promote an e-sport. Sadly I'm not sure there will be one. Controller Support - This game is limited in what you can  and can't use. Some of the most popular logitech wheels aren't supported, and you can't use multiple inputs in your setup. It doesn't support clutch pedals, so no manual override. My current rallying setup includes a shifter, a wheel, a pro 3 pedal setup, and a separate handbrake. It would not read the input from my handbrake at all - only my wheel as a game controller. Audio - You'll end up wanting to turn off the co-driver voice - which is about the worst thing I can think to do in a rallying game. It's like a robot that doesn't understand word structure or inflection, just belting out words over and over. It's hard to follow and doesn't sound realistic at all.  This game is planted firmly in contemporary rally, which is great if you are into it. however, after playing the game with multiple cars and setups I wasn't able to find anything interesting in trying different cars. There were differences, but not anything noteworthy enough to make the game seem fun. So that's the big thing for me. If it's not a sim, it should at least be fun. I'd have kept it if it were good at at least one of those things.

Introduction:I've been playing Rally games since I got a DOS version of Lombard RAC Rally in the late 80's and Championship Rally for the Nintendo back in the early 90's (my sons), and later  Rally Championship 2000,  RalliSport Challenge, all of the Colin McRae rally games through to Dirt 2  as well as the  later Dirt games, and  although not classed as rally games the early  road  racing Need for Speed games, Richard Burns Rally , Sega Rally,  Xpand Rally   plus a few others I've forgotten the names of.   I've   loved most of  them for various reasons and  WRC 5 is no exception.The latest iteration of World Rally Championship  v5 is IMO perhaps the best  in the WRC  franchise so far, with decent physics when driving on the various surfaces   such as gravel, snow dirt sand etc.  the sounds, including external  environmental sounds,  hitting various obstacles, the various  'tame' expletives your co driver  shouts  when you  crash or   have a near miss, are not the best, but all go to making  a decent  rally game experience.   For newcomers to rally games there's  a  useful  Rally School  mode and an easy driving styles  mode when playing  solo.    Modes of Play:Solo Mode:There are two main  modes of play, Solo and Multiplayer. Solo is divided into four more modes, 'Quick Stage', where you play just one stage of a rally, or   'Quick Rally' where you can choose to play any one of the rally  meets, including all of the stages. The third  solo mode  is   Career mode, where you play all of the championships  rally meets in a particular order; you can't  select   any rally, you have to play them in order according to the real World Championships, starting with the Monte Carlo Rally, then, you move to the next, i.e. Vodaphone Rally de Portugal etc etc.  Some stages in each rally are repeated but  with different road or environmental  conditions, such as day  and night, clear or icy etc.If you wish to start a new career,  you can do so, but it will wipe all progress  from the career you've already started.The final solo mode is the  Rally School, a useful tool if you are a novice, or not very confident rallying.    This is divided into five different   sections that initially cover the basics  such as pace notes, detailed angles, different kinds of turns and surfaces, accelerating and stopping on tarmac (the easiest surface to negociate), using the hand brakes etc.  Then there's coping with 2 wheel drive  4 wheel drive (two separate sections for this) and advanced techniques.  at the end of each section you have to put all you've learnt in that section together.  You are not able to skip any part of the  Rally School tutorials and you need to pass a certain standard in each  part to progress to the next.Multiplayer Mode and Leaderboards:The multiplayer options include online and offline multiplayer, quick match, online invitation and creating a private or public game.  These modes basically speak for themselves so there's  no need to go into detail.  The offline multiplayer  is  almost like playing single player, in that you race  singly between up to 8 players, each one  playing in turn, whereas with  the online multiplayer option, all players  race together, but  do not interact with each other (i.e, you can see them as Ghosts.  As I'm not primarily a multiplayer enthusiast, I can't expand on this area at this time.  I only like playing  vehicle based games online  with good friends as I'm embarrasingly  dire when it comes to technique and racing in general;  for example, looking at the world rankings for this game  20 hours into  the game being released  I stood at 377th out of 450  players, with a 45 second gap between my times and the leader and that was  just for one complete rally and championship type.  There are   three or four of these included in the game  (JWRC, WRC etc).  I felt like I was going as fast as the road conditions and my vehicle allowed,  yet being beaten by 45 seconds makes me wonder what I'm doing wrong.  Hopefully as I work through the rally school I'll improve somewhat. (fingers crossed). For those who are competitive, there are leader boards that show  overall  rankings for all players,  as well as  friends leader boards.Control Options:There are three configurable modes of control; Keyboard, Steering Wheel and Controller.  For any rally game enthusiast, the   Steering Wheel is the  best choice as you have more  'configurable' control over the keyboard,   and is the  most immersive control option;  for example you can  configure acceleration, brake and steering sensitivity with dead zones, whereas the  keyboard has no dead zones. The  Steering Wheel option also includes force feedback, (as does the Controller option) which gives a much greater feel and immersivness to the game, plus  your vehicle is much easier to control  compared to if you used a keyboard.  Unfortunately I've  still not unpacked my Logitech steering wheel, pedals and shifter since we moved house  (must do that soon). I've read that others have been having problems  with their  wheels not being supported.  Hopefully  this will be  addressed  in an update soon.  I found using the X-Box controller was  easier than the keyboard and included basic force feedback. There appears to be six degrees of freedom with this game, at least in some of the camera modes, for example, you can look from side to side, upwards and behind in  chase mode and in  cockpit mode  left and right and upwards.  Unfortunately the track IR hasn't been configured for any of the WTC games, so it's unlikely that we will be seeing  WRC5  Track IR enhanced, Maybe   Naturalpoint (the developers of the track IR system) may be considering  the latest title. The first 3 Dirt titles and some of the earlier Colin McRae as well as most of the other titles I mention at the beginning of this review   all have Track IR enhancements.  If this game gets it, it will add even more immersivness.The game also works with the Novint Falcon a force feedback device that gives excellent force feedback, but as the   device was primarily designed for mouse based games and  games with guns, it's not  as easy to control your driving unless you use it in conjuction with the keyboard.Driving Styles:There are four driving styles to choose from  starting with easy, through to medium, hard and  expert.  I've only played it on easy so far so can't  expand on the differences yet.  I will be updating this  review as and when I continue to play the game as I'm only on the second rally  at the moment.Repairing your vehicle:You can configure/tune you car  (in the motor home) for various conditions  to ensure optimal driving.  Skill alone  won't  see you winning every race because if you  haven't set up your car for the right conditions for the stage you are about to enter, you'll find your  vehicle will  damage more readily.  You can only  repair your vehicle between  the main stages in any  rally and   depending on how much damage you have   you are likely  not going to be able to repair everything  because you are only allowed   an amount of time that represents the  time allowed  in the real WRC  championship;  i.e. 45 minutes,  so you need to prioritise  which areas you  repair, for example geras, engine, body work,  brakes, electronics, steering etc.  for those less experienced with   the  more recent rally games (the  last WRC   game and I think the  later dirt games have a similar  repair  process) you can  set repairs to automatic. If you select this the A.I. will repair what it considers the  most urgent  repairs. However, don't  ignore the manual process entirely because   damage can also be dependant on the players  style. 												TL;DR consider getting this game if you want an arcady and more easy rally game.Full story:Many reviews seem to be comparing this game to Dirt Rally (I own both of these games), and the way this game is marketed suggests it is a rally simulator. However, people, who search for rally simulator will not find it here, because this game has quite arcady driving and damage models. That certainly will not appeal to Dirt Rally crowd, but I think people who are not into hardcore racing simulators would enjoy this game: this game has rally school, much less steep learning curve and it can be enjoyed without having a racing wheel. The tradeoff is not that realistic driving.Is it better than WRC 4? Yes. It runs smoothly at 60 FPS (older game was locked to 30), the graphics seem to be a big improvement over WRC 4. The amount of cars is decent, but less than Dirt Rally offers and classes are limited to WRC, WRC-2 and J-WRC. The price compared to amount of content on offer (comparing to Dirt Rally) is quite high, but if you can get it on sale, it is worth the money.Cons: it suffers from problem WRC 4 had as well: many special stages are on same pieces of road, so amount of unique roads is much smaller than number of stages. The rewind feature seems to be missing from WRC 4, now you just can restart from last checkpoint. Some signs of poor port from consoles to PC: key prompts seems to be bugged out, a lot of times Xbox controller prompts are shonwn for me when I only own a Logitech Driving Force GT, which has PS3 buttons on it.As a conclusion I can say if you are into hardcore racing simulators, you own a decent raging wheel, then get Dirt Rally, it is much better game for you. If you are into more arcady and more casual fun, this might be worth it for you.

												7.5/10 - Worth a visit, at the right price, for any rally fan.First Impressions+ 9 patches on pc, Kylotonn appears to be very committed and is listening to the community.+ nice simple to navigate menus (though some may not be happy with no mouse control).+ (since latest patches) able to detect all 3 components of my wheel setup.  including my Fanatec CSR Elite pedals and Thrustmater TH8A as separate USB conenctions.- wish it would detect the Thrustmater TH8A in analog mode for handbrake (instead of needing to use sequential mode).- overall sound needs improvement, engine sounds especially.  co-driver could also use work, has awkward pauses and sounds robotic.Graphics and Visual Impression+ runs just fine on triple screens (but no advanced rendering options).  appears to be well optimized (almost always 60 fps on triples with a single gtx 970).- overall the visuals can't match visuals of DiRT Rally or other AAA racing games.- no FOV or ability for full camera adjustments (but cockpit does give 5 view distance options).- tracks could use more activity from crowd or wildlife.  feels lifeless.Handling and Physics+ decent damage modeling that effects handling (but have yet to see a full retirment).  few smart ideas with damage; stuck in a gear, loss of co-driver audio (electronics issues), etc.  fairly realistic repair format at service stops (can't fix tyres by 3%).= sim-cade physics.  heavy cars and plenty of lateral grip when coasting makes it very easy to drive, but trail braking in to corners, and too heavy of accelreation in or out of corners can still be punished.  reminds me a lot of Colin McRae 2005 and similar... it's a very enjoyable drive, while not totally realistic.= average at best force feedback.  advanced wheel options are lacking, but I've been able to get it to feel good at 900 degrees of rotation.Track Selection+ no deja vu, all 65 stages are unique.  353.7 KM of stages, 5 for each of the 13 coutries (one is repeated in a rally).  This is double that found in DiRT Rally, and still more a bit more than the 300 km quoted by Seb Loeb Rally Evo.+ enjoyable stage designs, that feel authentic to the region.  reasonable track widths (not extremely wide and unrealistic).  good variation in terrain and turn types and corner combinations.- stages are not real world recreations, as featured in DiRT Rally and Seb Loeb Rally Evo.- some stages are very (2-3 km) short.  overall average is 5.4 km per stage (longest is 11 km).Overall ExperienceI'm really enjoying my time with WRC 5.  Those who only care about simulations can skip this title.  But if you're someone who is willing to play something a little more casual, you should be able to easily enjoy this experience.  Thing that makes rally awesome is learning new roads/routes... and this game will let you do that at a great volume.  Career mode is interesting enough as you make your climb from Junior, WRC 2, and finally to WRC.

												Update: I have stayed away from this game for some time and went back for another go. There have been small improvements in some areas, but, the fact that they are trying to pass this off as anything other than an arcade handling model is laughable. The game can be so much more. The FFB is stronger, but, makes no effort to give you any "feeling" of what your auto is doing. In Mexico,; there are a lot of turns and such with visable deep rutts, which I purposefully drove through and had no feedback at all and then when the road was smooth I received weird strong vibrations as if I was driving on a rumble strip. The fact that this game is connected to the Official WRC license is a waste in my opinion. It could have and definately SHOULD have been done far better. EDIT: I have had to change my previous endorsment of this abortion. They have managed to com[letely make the game unplayable for many players, stuttering and frame rate issues that make the game unplayable and we get "future patches to fix stuttering and frame rate issues". So STAY FAR AWAY until they fix it or Loeb comes out. This game has a few issues, THE BIGGEST being the pace notes, and it is far from the quality of DIRT Rally. But it is fun. The game has decent graphics if run in DX11 Mode and it has okay FFB. The stages are cool as they are "real" WRC stages and some are pretty long. They do cut and paste a lot just like DIRT but they have all the "Official" WRC Countries. There really is not much feedback from road surfaces, but , if you go off track into the grass or what not - it does give you some feedback for that. It does not have much in the way of surface changes like dirt simulates well, and the little differences in surface will not be sent through the wheel. it doesnt really alter much from the road surfaces even though there are visual clues of uneven road and rutts and the like. It just doesnt feel any different physically.The physics are not by any means "SIM" but they do have a difference in 2 wheel and 4 wheel drive and the weather makes a difference also. It is not gonna be "Game of The Year" but if you can pick it up on sale it is worth the price of admission.  I paid $35 US and think I may have paid a little too much, but, it really is not that bad of a game. Takes some getting used to. The cars seem to behave strange til you dial in the FFB settings and the controller settings. I would recommend this to anyone who is a Rally fan who doesnt expect too much from it. I have DIRT Rally and thats the game i would get if i could only have one of the two, but, if you can get both - it is great fun after you adjust to it. And I am sure they will patch some of the small bugs and optimize it a little more, at least I hope they will.
